title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.

The Chronocyclegraph was developed by Frank Gilbreth and his wife, Lillian in the early 20th century. The couple employed small lamps on worker's hands and time-lapse photography to reduce a work cycle to the most efficient sequence. Gilbreth was the first to propose that a nurse could assist the surgeon, by handing them surgical instruments. He also devised the techniques used to teach how to rapidly disassemble and reassemble weapons.

In "ConvNeXt V2: Co-designing and Scaling ConvNets with Masked Autoencoders" researchers co-design the convolutional network architecture with masked autoencoding for self-supervised learning: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00808

title: Weird 19th-Century Punctuation Marks You Should Try Using

last_post.content:
Okay people, I've got some NEW PUNCTUATION for you

The "commash", the "colash", and the "semi-colash"

Back in the 19th century, writers used these *everywhere*. It's hard to open a book to a random page and *not* see one

Yet in the 20th century, they vanished -- practically overnight

It's up to us to BRING THEM BACK

My essay is here, for Medium subscribers: https://clivethompson.medium.com/weird-19th-century-punctuation-marks-you-should-try-using-49d2e2516e5e

If you're not a Medium subscriber, here's a "friend" link: https://clivethompson.medium.com/weird-19th-century-punctuation-marks-you-should-try-using-49d2e2516e5e?sk=0b0b750a1dc3cf296efbf036ebbd2d34

Photographs of buildings ARE derivative, since they couldn’t exist without the original artistry of the building. But should photographers pay licensing fees to architects?

My point is that derivative vs. transformative vs. plagiarism is not a simple question, nor is it a new one.

title: What do Vision Transformers Learn? A Visual Exploration

last_post.content:
"What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration."

Vision transformers (ViTs) have fewer inductive biases the convolutional networks, so, what do ViTs actually learn? It turns out that they learn inductive biases (or features) similar to convolutional networks!

Early layers capture edges and textures, and later layers learn more complex representations to capture broader concepts.

Paper: "What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration." (https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06727)

title: Data-driven identification of post-acute SARS-CoV-2 infection subphenotypes - Nature Medicine

last_post.content:
Randomly ended up taking a look at https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-02116-3 after wondering if some recent symptoms I've been having are #longcovid related.

It's so interesting to look at the difference between this study and how long COVID is discussed on social media (or https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eclinm.2021.101019). Maybe it's the choice in topic model / clustering or the curation of ICD-10 codes, but I wonder if symptoms like brain fog, generalized anxiety, and ME/CFS don't often make it into EHR.

These surprising facts are explained in detail here:

• Byron Schmuland, Random harmonic series, Amer. Math. Monthly 110 (2003), 407–416. http://www.stat.ualberta.ca/people/schmu/preprints/rhs.pdf

Other nice facts: the random harmonic series

± 1 ± ½ ± ⅓  ± ¼ ± ⅕ ± ⅙ ± ...

converges with probability 1. Its variance is π²/6. (This is easy enough that you might be able to show it yourself!) And the probability that it exceeds some number x ≥ 0 is

≤ exp(−3𝑥²/π²)

so it's rarely very big.

(3/n, n = 3)

- Commit to fewer, better projects

- Seek out projects that fuel my soul

- Prioritize rest and self-care rather than glamorizing “the grind”

- Find joy in every step of the creative process

- Treat my fellow creatives as collaborators, not competitors

- Vet the platforms and tools I use to make my art

- Share knowledge and best practices to foster a culture of learning and mentorship

- Embrace the unique perspective I bring to my art and creativity
